name: rnafusion-cancer-detection
title: Gene Fusion Detection for Cancer RNA-seq
description: Detect oncogenic fusion genes in tumor RNA-seq data using multiple validated algorithms. Identify actionable therapeutic targets like ALK, ROS1, RET, and FGFR fusions for precision cancer medicine. Samplesheet format: `sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,strandedness`
content:
🧬 Gene Fusion Detection for Cancer RNA-seq

Discover Targetable Fusion Genes Driving Cancer Growth

Gene fusions occur when two previously separate genes become joined together, creating hybrid oncogenes that can drive cancer development. This pipeline uses three complementary fusion detection algorithms (STAR-Fusion, arriba, FusionCatcher) to provide robust, consensus-based identification of fusion genes from tumor RNA sequencing data.

🎯 What Are Gene Fusions?

Gene fusions result from chromosomal rearrangements (translocations, inversions, deletions) that join two genes together. In cancer, these fusions often create:

  • 🔥 Constitutively active kinases: Always "on" signaling proteins that drive uncontrolled growth

  • 🧬 Chimeric transcription factors: Aberrant gene regulators that reprogram cell identity

  • 🎯 Targetable vulnerabilities: Dependencies that can be exploited with specific inhibitor drugs

  • 📊 Diagnostic markers: Unique signatures that define cancer subtypes

🩺 Clinically Actionable Fusions in Cancer

💊 FDA-Approved Targeted Therapies

  • ALK fusions (lung cancer, ALCL): Crizotinib, alectinib, brigatinib, lorlatinib

  • ROS1 fusions (lung cancer, glioblastoma): Crizotinib, entrectinib

  • RET fusions (lung cancer, thyroid): Selpercatinib, pralsetinib

  • NTRK fusions (pan-cancer): Larotrectinib, entrectinib

  • FGFR fusions (cholangiocarcinoma, bladder): Pemigatinib, erdafitinib

  • BCR-ABL1 (CML, ALL): Imatinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, ponatinib

🔬 Common Cancer-Specific Fusions

🫁 Lung Cancer (NSCLC)

  • ALK fusions: 3-5% of NSCLC, younger patients, non-smokers

  • ROS1 fusions: 1-2% of NSCLC, excellent response to crizotinib

  • RET fusions: 1-2% of NSCLC, now targetable with selpercatinib

  • NTRK fusions: Rare but highly responsive to larotrectinib

🎗️ Breast Cancer

  • FGFR2/3 fusions: Subset of ER+ breast cancer

  • NTRK fusions: Rare, secretory breast carcinoma

  • ESR1 fusions: Treatment resistance mechanism

🩸 Prostate Cancer

  • TMPRSS2-ERG: Most common, ~50% of prostate cancers

  • TMPRSS2-ETV1/4: Alternative ETS fusions

  • SLC45A3-ERG: Subset of ERG-positive cancers

🦴 Sarcomas

  • EWS-FLI1: Ewing sarcoma (85%), diagnostic fusion

  • SS18-SSX: Synovial sarcoma (>95%), diagnostic

  • PAX3/7-FOXO1: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, prognostic

  • COL1A1-PDGFB: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans

🧠 Gliomas

  • FGFR-TACC: Pediatric and adult gliomas, potentially targetable

  • BRAF fusions: Pilocytic astrocytoma, alternative to BRAF V600E

  • NTRK fusions: Rare but highly responsive

🦋 Thyroid Cancer

  • RET/PTC fusions: Papillary thyroid cancer (20-40%)

  • PAX8-PPARG: Follicular thyroid carcinoma

  • NTRK fusions: Subset of papillary thyroid cancer

🔍 Why Use Multiple Fusion Detection Algorithms?

This pipeline integrates three complementary fusion callers for maximum sensitivity and specificity:

  • 🌟 STAR-Fusion: Fast, splice-aware, excellent for common fusions

    • Leverages STAR aligner's chimeric read detection

    • Optimized for speed and accuracy

    • Good at filtering false positives

  • 🎨 arriba: High sensitivity, excellent visualization

    • Detects fusions missed by other callers

    • Provides fusion gene diagrams and breakpoint plots

    • Good for novel/rare fusions

  • 🔬 FusionCatcher: Comprehensive, well-established

    • Extensive filtering against false positives

    • Large database of known fusions

    • Good for clinical-grade detection

Consensus approach benefits:

  • ✅ Higher confidence: Fusions detected by multiple callers are more reliable

  • ✅ Better sensitivity: Different algorithms catch different fusion types

  • ✅ Reduced false positives: Consensus filtering removes artifacts

  • ✅ Comprehensive coverage: Rare and common fusions both detected

🧪 Experimental Design Requirements

Sample Types

  • 🧬 Fresh frozen tumor RNA: Optimal quality, highest sensitivity

  • 📦 FFPE tumor RNA: Acceptable but may reduce sensitivity

  • 🩸 Liquid biopsy (ctRNA): Possible but requires very deep sequencing

  • 🧫 Cell line RNA: Ideal for validation and positive controls

Sequencing Specifications

  • 📊 Read type: Paired-end (required for optimal fusion detection)

  • 📏 Read length: 100bp or 150bp (longer is better for spanning breakpoints)

  • 🎯 Depth: 50-100 million paired reads minimum (100-200M for comprehensive detection)

  • ✅ Quality: RIN ≥ 7 recommended, ≥ 5 acceptable for FFPE

  • 🧬 Library: Standard mRNA-seq (poly-A selection or rRNA depletion)

Controls and Validation

  • ✅ Positive controls: Cell lines with known fusions (e.g., K562 = BCR-ABL1)

  • ⚖️ Negative controls: Matched normal tissue RNA (optional but useful)

  • 🔁 Technical replicates: For validation studies

  • 📊 Biological replicates: Multiple tumors for discovery studies

📋 Sample Sheet Format

Your CSV samplesheet defines samples and their properties:

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,strandedness
Tumor_Patient1,Patient1_tumor_R1.fastq.gz,Patient1_tumor_R2.fastq.gz,forward
Tumor_Patient2,Patient2_tumor_R1.fastq.gz,Patient2_tumor_R2.fastq.gz,forward
Control_K562,K562_R1.fastq.gz,K562_R2.fastq.gz,forward

Column Descriptions:

  • sample: Unique sample name (no spaces, letters/numbers/underscores only)

  • fastq_1: Path to Read 1 FASTQ file (must be .fastq.gz or .fq.gz)

  • fastq_2: Path to Read 2 FASTQ file (leave empty for single-end, but paired-end recommended)

  • strandedness: Library strandedness - "forward", "reverse", or "unstranded"

    • "forward" = dUTP/NSR/NNSR method (most common)

    • "reverse" = Ligation method (TruSeq stranded)

    • "unstranded" = Standard RNA-seq without strand information

    • If unsure, use "unstranded" (works but slightly less accurate)

🧬 Reference Genome (GRCh38 Only)

Important: nf-core/rnafusion only supports human genome GRCh38/hg38.

  • ✅ GRCh38/hg38: Latest human reference, required by this pipeline

  • ❌ GRCh37/hg19: NOT supported (legacy reference)

  • ❌ Other organisms: NOT supported (human-specific fusion databases)

The pipeline uses pre-built fusion gene references optimized for GRCh38.

📊 Comprehensive Output Files

Fusion Gene Results

  • 🎯 VCF file: Standardized variant call format with all detected fusions

  • 📄 TSV reports: Tab-separated tables with fusion details

    • Fusion gene names (5' and 3' partners)

    • Breakpoint coordinates

    • Supporting read counts

    • In-frame vs out-of-frame prediction

    • Known oncogenic fusion annotations

  • 📊 HTML report: Interactive visualizations and quality metrics

  • 📈 PDF report: Publication-ready fusion diagrams and breakpoint plots

Per-Caller Results

  • STAR-Fusion output: Fast detection results

  • arriba output: High-sensitivity results with visualization

  • FusionCatcher output: Comprehensive filtered results

  • Consensus fusions: Aggregated results from multiple callers

Additional Analysis

  • 🧬 StringTie transcripts: Full transcript assembly for expression context

  • ✂️ CTAT-Splicing: Aberrant splicing events near fusion breakpoints

  • 📊 MultiQC report: Comprehensive quality control metrics

    • Read quality and alignment statistics

    • Detection sensitivity estimates

    • Sample-level QC metrics

Visualization Files

  • 🎨 Fusion gene diagrams: Visual representation of gene structure and breakpoints

  • 📈 Breakpoint plots: Read coverage around fusion junctions

  • 🧬 Transcript illustrations: Predicted fusion protein domains

🔬 Interpreting Results

High Confidence Fusions (Priority for Follow-up)

  • ✅ Detected by 2+ callers (consensus increases confidence)

  • ✅ ≥10 supporting reads (well-supported)

  • ✅ In-frame fusion (likely produces functional protein)

  • ✅ Known oncogenic fusion (in COSMIC/FusionGDB databases)

  • ✅ Involves cancer-related genes (kinases, transcription factors)

Lower Confidence Fusions (Require Validation)

  • ⚠️ Detected by single caller only

  • ⚠️ <5 supporting reads (may be artifact)

  • ⚠️ Out-of-frame (unlikely to be functional)

  • ⚠️ Novel fusion not in databases (could be real or artifact)

  • ⚠️ Involves read-through transcription (adjacent genes, often not pathogenic)

Validation Methods

  • 🔬 RT-PCR: Confirm fusion transcript by targeted amplification

  • 🧬 Sanger sequencing: Validate exact breakpoint sequence

  • 🎯 FISH: Confirm chromosomal rearrangement at DNA level

  • 🧫 Functional assays: Test if fusion has oncogenic properties

🩺 Clinical Applications

  • 💊 Precision therapy selection: Match patients to targeted therapies (ALK/ROS1/RET inhibitors)

  • 🧬 Molecular diagnosis: Confirm cancer subtype by diagnostic fusion (e.g., EWS-FLI1 in Ewing sarcoma)

  • 📊 Prognostic stratification: Identify high-risk vs favorable fusions

  • 🔬 Clinical trial enrollment: Identify patients eligible for fusion-targeted trials

  • 🩸 Minimal residual disease: Monitor fusion-positive cells during treatment

  • 🔄 Resistance mechanisms: Detect resistance fusions after targeted therapy

⚙️ Pipeline Technical Details

  • 🔧 Alignment: STAR 2-pass mode for optimal fusion detection

  • 🎯 Fusion callers: STAR-Fusion, arriba, FusionCatcher (all three enabled)

  • 📊 Quality control: FastQC, MultiQC with fusion-specific metrics

  • ✅ Filtering: Stringent default filters to minimize false positives

  • 🧬 Annotation: Known fusion databases (COSMIC, FusionGDB, ChimerDB)

  • 📈 Visualization: Automated PDF and HTML reports

  • 🔬 Additional analysis: StringTie transcript assembly, CTAT-Splicing

🎯 Expected Runtime and Resources

  • ⏱️ Runtime: 4-8 hours for typical samples (50-100M reads)

  • 💾 Storage: ~20-50 GB per sample for intermediate and final files

  • 🖥️ Resources: Automatically managed, scales with data size

  • ✅ Node size: XSMALL for test data, MEDIUM for typical samples, LARGE for deep sequencing

Perfect for Research in: Cancer genomics • Precision oncology • Translational research • Clinical diagnostics • Drug target discovery • Biomarker identification • Sarcoma research • Leukemia profiling

Built with Nextflow • Powered by nf-core/rnafusion v4.0.0 • Containerized execution • Clinically validated algorithms
